name: Dummy Deck
description: Sandbox for testing new technical phrases before migration.

cards.sideA: El texto esta escrito en primera persona.

sideB.text: The text is written in the first person.
The text is in the first person.
The writing is in the first person.

cards.note:
Use [written in] for passive voice structures.

~The text is written by first person~ is incorrect because we use the preposition 'in' to describe the perspective or voice. Use [written in].

cards.sideA: Pidele en el prompt que te responda en tercera persona.

sideB.text: Ask it in the prompt to reply in the third person.
Tell it to respond in the third person within the prompt.
In the prompt, ask for a response in the third person.

cards.note:
When interacting with AI, [ask it to] is standard for commands.

~answer your in the third person~ is incorrect because 'your' is a possessive adjective and needs a noun. Use [answer you].

cards.sideA: Pidele que no te conteste en segunda persona.

sideB.text: Ask it not to answer you in the second person.
Tell it not to reply using the second person.
Ask for the response to not be in the second person.
Ask him not to answer you in the second person.

cards.note: Negative command: [Ask it not to] + [verb].

cards.sideA: ¿Que le pasa a el?

sideB.text: What is wrong with him?
What's going on with him?
What's happening to him?
What happens to him?

cards.note:
**[160]**

[What's wrong with...] is the most common way to ask about someone's state.

~What does he happen?~ is not valid because 'happen' is an intransitive verb where the subject is the event, not the person. Use [What happened to him?].

cards.sideA: ¿Que le paso a ella?

sideB.text: What happened to her?
What went on with her?
What was the matter with her?

cards.note:
**[160]**

[What happened] is the standard past tense for occurrences.

~What did it happen to her?~ is incorrect because 'happen' is intransitive and doesn't use the 'it' dummy subject in this specific question structure. Use [What happened to her?].

cards.sideA: No se como se dice ese oficio.

sideB.text: I don't know how to say that job.
I'm not sure how to call that trade.
I don't know the word for that profession.

cards.note: [Trade] or [Job] are natural for 'oficio'.

cards.sideA: (Solo puedes arrastrar y soltar los archivos aquí).

sideB.text: You can just drag and drop the files here.
You can only drag and drop files in this area.
Simply drag and drop your files here.

cards.note: [Drag and drop] is the standard UI terminology.

cards.sideA: (Usa la función de arrastrar y soltar para subir tu foto).

sideB.text: Use the drag-and-drop feature to upload your photo.
Use drag and drop to submit your picture.
You can use the drag-and-drop tool for your photo.

cards.note: When used as an adjective, it is hyphenated: [drag-and-drop] feature.

cards.sideA: (Este sitio web tiene una interfaz de arrastrar y soltar muy fácil).

sideB.text: This website has a very easy drag-and-drop interface.
The drag-and-drop interface on this site is very simple.
This site offers a user-friendly drag-and-drop UI.
This website has a very easy drag-and-drop UI.

cards.note: [User-friendly] is a common way to say something is easy to use.

cards.sideA: Un embedding convierte palabras en una lista de números.

sideB.text: An embedding turns words into a list of numbers.
Embeddings transform text into numerical lists.
An embedding converts language into a sequence of numbers.
An embedding transforms words into a list of numbers.

cards.note:
**[146]**

[Turns into] or [Converts into] are perfect for data transformations.

~transforms words in a list~ is incorrect for describing a conversion. Use [turns words into] or [transforms words into].

cards.sideA: Los embeddings representan el texto como coordenadas.

sideB.text: Embeddings represent text as coordinates.
Embeddings treat text as spatial coordinates.
Text is represented as coordinates through embeddings.

cards.note: [Represent as] is the standard technical term.

cards.sideA: Un vector es una lista de números llamada arreglo.

sideB.text: A vector is a list of numbers called an array.
Vectors are lists of numbers known as arrays.
An array is a list of numbers that represents a vector.

cards.note:
[Called] or [Known as] are used to define terms.

~which are called array~ has subject-verb agreement issues (a list is...). Use [which is called an array] or [known as an array].

cards.sideA: Los vectores representan la ubicación exacta de un concepto.

sideB.text: Vectors represent the exact location of a concept.
Vectors show the precise position of a concept.
A vector maps the exact location of an idea.

cards.note:
[Maps] is a high-level verb for representing locations/relationships.

~ubication~ is a false friend from the Spanish 'ubicación'. Use [location].

cards.sideA: La búsqueda semántica busca el significado en lugar de palabras clave exactas.

sideB.text: Semantic search looks for meaning instead of exact keywords.
Semantic search focuses on intent rather than just keywords.
Instead of keywords, semantic search identifies the meaning.
Semantic search seeks meaning instead of exact keywords.

cards.note: [Instead of] is used to contrast two methods.

cards.sideA: La búsqueda semántica conecta 'abogado' con 'leyes' automáticamente.

sideB.text: Semantic search connects 'lawyer' with 'laws' automatically.
Semantic search links 'lawyer' and 'laws' by itself.
The system automatically associates 'lawyer' with 'laws'.

cards.note: [Associates with] is a formal synonym for 'connects'.

cards.sideA: RAG obliga a la IA a consultar una biblioteca antes de responder.

sideB.text: RAG forces the AI to check a library before answering.
RAG makes the AI look up data before responding.
With RAG, the AI must consult a knowledge base first.
RAG forces the AI to query a library before answering.

cards.note:
[Knowledge base] is the technical term for the 'biblioteca' in RAG.

~ensures the AI to check~ is grammatically incorrect. 'Ensure' should be followed by a 'that' clause. Use [forces the AI to check].

cards.sideA: RAG evita que la IA invente hechos.

sideB.text: RAG prevents the AI from making up facts.
RAG stops the AI from hallucinating facts.
RAG keeps the AI from inventing information.

cards.note:
[Hallucinating] is the industry term for an AI inventing facts.

~avoids the AI from making up facts~ is incorrect; 'avoid' is followed by a gerund directly. ~prevents the AI make up facts~ is missing the preposition 'from'. Use [prevents the AI from making up].

cards.sideA: RAG combina un motor de búsqueda con un modelo de lenguaje.

sideB.text: RAG combines a search engine with a language model.
RAG merges a search engine and a language model.
RAG is a combination of a search engine and an LLM.

cards.note: [LLM] stands for Large Language Model.

cards.sideA: Un pipeline es una secuencia de pasos automatizados.

sideB.text: A pipeline is a sequence of automated steps.
Pipelines are series of automated actions.
A pipeline refers to a chain of automated processes.

cards.note: [Chain of] is a good alternative for 'secuencia'.

cards.sideA: Los datos fluyen a través del pipeline de principio a fin.

sideB.text: Data flows through the pipeline from start to finish.
Information travels the pipeline from beginning to end.
Data goes through the entire pipeline.
Data flows through the pipeline from end to end.

cards.note: [From start to finish] is the idiomatic way to say 'de principio a fin'.

cards.sideA: Los pipelines ayudan a organizar flujos de trabajo de IA complejos.

sideB.text: Pipelines help organize complex AI workflows.
Pipelines are useful for managing complex AI workflows.
Complex AI workflows are organized using pipelines.

cards.note: [Workflows] is the standard term for 'flujos de trabajo'.

cards.sideA: Un cluster es un grupo de servidores trabajando juntos.

sideB.text: A cluster is a group of servers working together.
Clusters are sets of servers operating in unison.
A group of servers working as one is called a cluster.

cards.note: [Working together] is simple and clear.

cards.sideA: Un cluster asegura que el sistema siga en línea si un servidor falla.

sideB.text: A cluster ensures the system stays online if one server fails.
Clusters guarantee uptime even if a server goes down.
A cluster keeps the system up if there is a server failure.

cards.note:
[Uptime] and [Stays online] are key for infrastructure.

~keeps online~ is not idiomatic. Use [stays online] or [remains online].

cards.sideA: LN en una variable significa 'Local number'.

sideB.text: LN in a variable stands for 'Local number'.
LN in a variable means 'Local number'.
The prefix LN usually represents 'Local number'.

cards.note: [Stands for] is commonly used for acronyms.

cards.sideA: La letra S significa Éxito

sideB.text: The letter S means Success.
The letter S stands for Success.
S represents Success in this context.

cards.note: Common flag in programming logic.

cards.sideA: La letra E significa Error

sideB.text: The letter E means Error.
The letter E stands for Error.
E is used to indicate an Error.

cards.note: Standard error flag.

cards.sideA: La letra U significa Error Inesperado

sideB.text: The letter U means Unexpected Error.
The letter U stands for Unexpected Error.
U represents an Unexpected Error status.

cards.note: [Unexpected] is used for errors not handled by specific logic.

cards.sideA: El código 200 significa Éxito

sideB.text: Code 200 means Success.
The 200 code represents a successful request.
A 200 status code indicates Success.

cards.note: Standard HTTP status for OK.

cards.sideA: El código 400 significa Error

sideB.text: Code 400 means Error.
The 400 code indicates a Bad Request or Error.
Status code 400 stands for a client-side Error.
The 400 code means Error.
400 code means Error.

cards.note: [Bad Request] is the official name for HTTP 400.

cards.sideA: La letra A significa Activo

sideB.text: The letter A means Active.
The letter A stands for Active.
A represents the Active status.

cards.note: Common flag for database statuses.

cards.sideA: La letra Y significa Verdadero

sideB.text: The letter Y means True.
The letter Y stands for Yes or True.
Y represents a True boolean value.

cards.note: [Y] is usually 'Yes', representing 'True'.

cards.sideA: La letra N significa Falso o No.

sideB.text: The letter N stands for False or No.
The letter N means No or False.
N represents a False value.

cards.note: [N] is usually 'No', representing 'False'.

cards.sideA: La letra F significa Falso

sideB.text: The letter F stands for False.
The letter F means False.
F is used to represent a False boolean.

cards.note:
Direct boolean representation.

~The F letter~ is incorrect word order. In English, we place the specific identifier after the category. Use [The letter F].

cards.sideA: El record creado en otro paquete esta siendo poblado ahi

sideB.text: The record created in another package is being populated there.
That's where the record from a different package gets populated.
The record from another package is being filled in there.

cards.note: [Is being populated] is the technical way to say data is being inserted/filled.

cards.sideA: Los campos del record de otro paquete estan populandose ahi

sideB.text: The fields of the record from another package are being populated there.
That's where the record fields from another package are filled.
Record fields from a different package are being populated right there.

cards.note: [Fields] are the specific attributes within a [Record].
